item.title: Live Updates: South Korean Leader Will Face Impeachment Vote Over Martial Law Declaration
item.description: Lawmakers filed a motion to remove President Yoon Suk Yeol, reflecting the fury over his audacious response to political gridlock. He lifted martial law within hours, and plans to address the nation on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Why South Korea’s Leader Made Such a Fateful Decision
item.description: ​A day after he declared — and then withdrew — martial law, President Yoon Suk Yeol was politically isolated as observers pondered his future in leadership.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters blocking a military vehicle outside the National Assembly in Seoul on Wednesday, after President Yoon Suk Yeol declared emergency martial law.

item.title: Writers Silenced by Stalin Get New Life Amid War in Ukraine
item.description: The Soviet regime killed a generation of literary artists in the 1930s. Their legacy is being reclaimed as Ukraine fights to preserve its cultural heritage.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A performance of “You [Romance],” a play chronicling the lives of the “Executed Renaissance” directed by Oleksandr Khomenko, in Kyiv, Ukraine, in October.

item.title: With Assad Challenged, a Push to Cut Syria’s Ties to Iran Grows More Unlikely
item.description: Even as Israel bombarded Syria, officials say the U.S. and Gulf countries were working to weaken its president’s alliance with Tehran. Rebels’ shock advance has dampened those hopes.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Ronen Bergman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Images of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, center, and Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, south of Damascus, in March.

item.title: Tapped by Trudeau to Steer Foreign Affairs, She’s Now His Possible Successor
item.description: Mélanie Joly, Canada’s top diplomat, has already faced off against India and China, with Donald Trump up next. She’s also considered a top contender to replace Justin Trudeau.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mélanie Joly, Canada’s minister of foreign affairs, at her home in Montreal in July.

item.title: Syrian Forces Battle Rebels Outside Key City of Hama
item.description: The rebels have set their sights on an area where President Bashar al-Assad’s government has long maintained strength.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Syrian military equipment abandoned on the road near Suran, north of Hama, on Tuesday.

item.title: Georgia Tumbles Deeper Into Crisis as Opposition Leader is Detained
item.description: In a sign of a widening crackdown, security agents have searched the offices and homes of prominent activists and opposition leaders who fear the country is turning closer to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video shows Nika Gvaramia, an opposition leader, surrounded by police officers before being detained in Tbilisi, Georgia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Releases Narges Mohammadi, Nobel Laureate, From Prison for 21 Days
item.description: The activist, whose health has deteriorated, had bone surgery last month.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Zelensky Offers $24 One-Off Payment to Win Over War-Weary Ukrainians
item.description: Citizens will be entitled to a $24 one-off payment this winter, President Volodymyr Zelensky announced, in a move apparently intended to soften the blow of a tax rise to help fund the war effort.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A butcher in Myrnohrad, Ukraine, in November. The grant is a modest sum compared to the average monthly salary in Ukraine of roughly $500.

item.title: For Some Koreans, Martial Law Stirs Harrowing Memories of Gwangju Uprising
item.description: “I immediately thought of 1980, and the fear and desperation we felt,” said a 60-year-old lawmaker who lived through the massacre of protesters in Gwangju.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers outside the National Assembly in Seoul on Tuesday night.

item.title: Amid Syria’s Rebel Offensive, a Geopolitical Cauldron Simmers
item.description: Iran and Russia, both stretched by conflicts of their own, have experienced setbacks in Syria after a rebel offensive in the northwest of the country.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Syrian opposition fighters last month. They have made their most significant advance in years against government forces, shaking up a civil war that had long been at a stalemate.

item.title: Why Israel and Hezbollah Are Still Firing Amid a Lebanon Cease-Fire
item.description: Some violations of the truce, and some amount of violence, are to be expected, analysts say, and do not necessarily mean the deal will collapse and war will resume anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Israeli troops leaving Lebanon on their way back to Israel, as seen from the Israeli side of the border, on Monday.

item.title: Netanyahu Welcomes Trump’s Demand to Free Hostages Before Inauguration
item.description: The Israeli leader’s comments came after President-elect Donald J. Trump threatened to take unspecified action unless the hostages held in Gaza are released by Jan. 20.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial for hostages kidnapped on Oct. 7, 2023, in Tel Aviv last month.

item.title: Biden, in Angola, Warns That Slavery’s History Should Not be Erased
item.description: In becoming the first American leader to visit Angola, President Biden said it was important not to forget the ugly legacy of the human trade that originally defined relations with Africa.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden outside the National Museum of Slavery in Luanda, Angola, on Tuesday.

item.title: Elite Sumo Wrestlers Will Compete in London, a Rarity Outside Japan
item.description: A five-day event in October will be the Japan Sumo Association’s first competition in Britain in more than three decades.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The sumo wrestlers Kitanowaka Daisuke and Fukutsuumi Akira of Japan outside Royal Albert Hall in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Stripping Down for a Night at a French Museum
item.description: To report on an unclothed visit to an exhibition about social nudism, a Times journalist chose to join the party. Her mother did, too.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: France Keyser for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors attended “Naturist Paradise” at the Museum of the Civilizations of Europe and the Mediterranean in Marseille, France.

item.title: Who Would Replace South Korea’s President Yoon?
item.description: Prime Minister Han Duck-soo would take over if President Yoon Suk Yeol steps down or is impeached.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:description: South Korean Prime Minister Han Duck-soo at the National Assembly in Seoul in November.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A political crisis in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the National Assembly in Seoul last night.

item.title: Nearly 300 Troops Stormed South Korea’s National Assembly, Official Says
item.description: The National Assembly’s secretary general, Kim Min-ki, condemned what he called the “illegal, unconstitutional actions of the military.”
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.media:description: South Korean troops at an entrance to the National Assembly in Seoul early Wednesday. Some protesters tried to push their way in.

item.title: South Korea Stock Markets Wobble After Martial Law Turmoil
item.description: Officials pledged “unlimited” support to markets as traders digested the implications of South Korea’s brief declaration of martial law.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Jason Karaian
item.media:description: Analysts and investors on Wednesday were trying to gauge how long South Korea’s outbreak of political turmoil would persist.

item.title: South Korean History Is Scarred by Martial Law
item.description: The president’s short-lived declaration of a military emergency late Tuesday was young South Koreans’ first exposure to a state of affairs their elders remember well.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Soldiers with bound pro-democracy protesters in Gwangju, South Korea, in 1980.

item.title: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea Declares Martial Law, Then Backs Down
item.description: Soon after President Yoon Suk Yeol’s declaration on Tuesday, lawmakers voted to defy him, prompting the president to say he was lifting his order.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, John Yoon, Jin Yu Young and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside the National Assembly in Seoul demanding an end to martial law on Tuesday.

item.title: Timeline: How Yoon’s Presidency in South Korea Led to Martial Law Order
item.description: Yoon Suk Yeol’s decree, and his reversal under pressure from lawmakers, were the culmination of years of feuding between the country’s two main political camps.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk Yeol being sworn into office in May 2022.

item.title: Who is Lee Jae-myung, South Korea’s Opposition Leader?
item.description: The opposition leader rallied lawmakers to vote down President Yoon Suk Yeol’s martial law decree.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, center, the opposition leader, speaking at the National Assembly in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: Namibia Elects Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah as Its First Female President
item.description: Across southern Africa, political parties that have led their countries since the end of colonialism have ceded power to the opposition in recent months. Namibia bucked the trend.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Timo Shihepo
item.category: South West Africa People's Organization (SWAPO) (Namibian Political Party)
item.media:description: Supporters of Netumbo Nandi-Ndaitwah during a campaign rally in Windhoek, Namibia, last month.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Brief Martial Law in South Korea
item.description: Plus, become a gladiator for a day.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, yesterday.

item.title: Italian Sentenced in Killing of Ex-Girlfriend, Giulia Cecchettin
item.description: The killing ignited national outrage and provoked calls for stronger measures to protect women.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A demonstrator holding a photo of Giulia Cecchettin at a march in Milan last year.

item.title: NATO Chief Urges More Weapons for Ukraine Ahead of Any Peace Talks
item.description: Mark Rutte said it was up to Ukraine to decide when it was ready to begin negotiations with Russia — and that the West should help strengthen Kyiv’s position beforehand.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Kim Barker
item.media:description: Mark Rutte, NATO Secretary General, right, with Ukrainian foreign minister, Andrii Sybiha, in Brussels on Tuesday.

item.title: Martial Law in South Korea Tests Biden and a Key U.S. Alliance
item.description: The Biden administration has hailed South Korea as a model democracy and bolstered military ties as it relies on the country as a bulwark against North Korea, China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: President Biden has put a special emphasis on South Korea, and invited President Yoon Suk Yeol to the White House last year.

item.title: Who Is Yoon Suk Yeol, South Korea’s President?
item.description: A conservative, Mr. Yoon won the presidency in 2022 by a slim margin, promising a more confrontational stance against North Korea. He quickly became unpopular and divisive at home.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoon Suk Yeol, the president of South Korea, in Seoul in 2022.

item.title: Why Was Martial Law Declared in South Korea?
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol faces public fury and calls to resign after he imposed martial law, then backed down after Parliament voted to repeal it.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, Jin Yu Young, John Yoon, Ephrat Livni and Qasim Nauman
item.media:credit: South Korea Presidential Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol during a press briefing on Tuesday at the presidential office in Seoul.

item.title: Chaos Plays Out at South Korea’s Legislature Building After Declaration of Martial Law
item.description: Soldiers wearing helmets and carrying long guns pushed back against people who tried to enter the National Assembly, after President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, Jin Yu Young, John Yoon and Tim Balk
item.media:description: A barricade made of chairs and cushions at the National Assembly in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: Read President Yoon’s Speech Declaring Martial Law in South Korea
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol made the extraordinary declaration in an unannounced speech to the nation on Tuesday night.
item.media:credit: South Korea Presidential Office, via Associated Press

item.title: Syria Fighting Worsens Already Dire Conditions in Idlib and Aleppo
item.description: Years of war and a powerful earthquake had led to crushing poverty, displacement and breakdowns in services. But over the last several days, the region’s misery deepened.
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Haj Kadour and Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Damage from an airstrike in Idlib, a rebel-held city in northern Syria, on Monday. Russian and Syrian fighter jets have targeted the area in recent days.

item.title: Investigation Into Forced Adoptions From Ukraine Points Finger at Putin
item.description: Yale researchers traced hundreds of children taken to Russia in the war, finding what they described as “a higher level of crime than first understood.”
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his commissioner for children, Maria Lvova-Belova, in a photo released by the Russian state news media in May. The International Criminal Court has issued warrants for their arrest.

item.title: China Announces a Ban on Rare Minerals to the U.S.
item.description: The move escalates supply chain warfare and comes a day after the Biden administration expanded curbs on the sale of advanced American technology to China.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Keith Bradsher and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: China, which produces almost all the world’s supply of critical minerals, has been tightening its grip on the materials.

item.title: Top U.N. Envoy Says Gaza War Followed Years of Weak Diplomacy
item.description: World leaders failed to focus on a permanent solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and risk making the same mistake again, the departing United Nations’ envoy in the region says.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Tor Wennesland, the top United Nations envoy for the Middle East peace process, says: “Politics failed. Diplomacy failed. The international community failed. And the parties failed.”

item.title: An Indigenous Group in Quebec Tries to Keep the Caribou Alive
item.description: The Canadian government is threatening to use emergency measures to protect three caribou herds at risk of dying out in Quebec.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean-Luc Kanapé’s fiberglass replica of a woodland caribou.

item.title: Airbnb ‘Gladiator’ Experience at the Colosseum Prompts Outcry in Rome
item.description: An initiative by officials at the monument in a partnership with Airbnb has prompted an outcry among those who feel it will demean a cultural treasure.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The Colosseum in 2020. Some people in Rome feel that gladiator re-enactments in the iconic amphitheater would be in poor taste.

item.title: From Chinese Patriot to American Spy: The Unusual Life of John Leung
item.description: He had been hailed by Chinese state media as a model for his efforts to promote Beijing’s interests in the United States. He was in fact an F.B.I. informant.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl, Joy Dong and Adam Goldman
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China

item.title: 3 Climbers From the U.S. and Canada Have Gone Missing on New Zealand’s Highest Mountain
item.description: Two Americans and a Canadian were climbing Aoraki/Mount Cook before failing to show up to a prearranged flight on Monday.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Aoraki/Mount Cook is the highest mountain in New Zealand.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russian and Iranian support for Syria.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Russian airstrike hit Idlib in northern Syria yesterday.

item.title: France’s Prime Minister Could Be Forced to Resign This Week. Here’s What Could Happen Next.
item.description: A vote by the lower house of Parliament could force the prime minister to resign, leaving his budget legislation in limbo.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France could face a no-confidence vote as soon as Wednesday, which, if it passes. would force him to resign.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: A Presidential Pardon
item.description: Plus, Free North Korea Radio.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: President Biden, left, and his son Hunter.

item.title: 5 Women Win Reparations From Belgium for Crimes Under Colonial Rule
item.description: In a landmark case, a court ruled that the women, now in their 70s and 80s, who were taken from their parents in Belgian Congo, were victims of a crime against humanity.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Elian Peltier
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Noelle Verbeken, Léa Tavares Mujinga and Simone Ngalula, three of the five women who sued the Belgian state for acts committed under colonial rule in Congo, in Brussels in 2021.

item.title: Trump Says There Will Be ‘Hell to Pay’ Unless Hostages in Gaza Are Released
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump said in a social media post on Monday that the hostages must be released before his inauguration in January.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images of hostage abducted to Gaza on Oct. 7, 2023, were displayed in Tel Aviv in February.

item.title: Maternity Leave and Ongoing Consent: New Rights for Belgium’s Sex Workers
item.description: A groundbreaking law, which gives some sex workers greater labor protections and social benefits than similar legislation elsewhere in the world, is now in effect in the European country.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Dirk Waem/Belga, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A bedroom in a brothel in the red light district of Ghent, Belgium.

item.title: What’s Behind the Protests in Georgia?
item.description: For days, pro-Western Georgians have clashed with police over the government’s plan to suspend plans for European Union membership.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: Hezbollah and Israel Trade Fire, Further Testing Cease-Fire
item.description: Both sides have accused each other of violating the deal; Hezbollah fired into Israel for the first time since the truce took effect, and Israel responded with airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers patrolling near the Lebanese border in Avivim, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: Who Is Massad Boulos, the Lebanese American Tycoon and Trump Adviser?
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has selected Mr. Boulos, the businessman and father-in-law of Mr. Trump’s daughter, as a senior adviser on Arab and Middle Eastern affairs.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Massad Boulos, who was named as President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for senior adviser on Arab and Middle Eastern affairs, spoke to The New York Times in Detroit in October.

item.title: An Arctic Hamlet Is Sinking Into the Thawing Permafrost
item.description: Canada is losing its permafrost to climate change. The Indigenous residents of Tuktoyaktuk know they’ll have to move but don’t agree on when.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times

item.title: French Government Faces No-Confidence Vote Over Budget Bill
item.description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier pushed a budget bill through the lower house of Parliament without a vote. A no-confidence vote this week could topple him and his cabinet.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier, center, at the Parliament in Paris last month.

item.title: Who Are the Syrian Rebels Who Seized Aleppo?
item.description: The group now advancing, Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, says it wants to replace the Assad government with one inspired by Islamic principles.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Alissa J. Rubin and Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fighter from Hayat Tahrir al-Sham at a frontline base in Maaret al-Naasan, Syria, in 2021. For several years, the group focused on securing and governing the area it held.

item.title: Russia and Iran Pledge Support for Syria’s al-Assad Against Advancing Rebels
item.description: In just a few days, a patchwork of rebel forces has seized control of a broad stretch of land in the west and northwest of Syria. But it’s unclear just how much support Syria’s weakened allies can provide.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath of an airstrike that targeted Syria’s rebel-held northern city of Idlib on Monday.
